header.topics: Australia, business men's clothing, Queensland, bank loans, Sheffield dialect, Bristol, teaching, Southerners, farewells
header.activity: comparative strangers talking bout visiting and working in Australia, and Sheffield dialect

body.u: out of er Street Brisbane and course up at Isa and he wanted to they wanted to transfer me to from to run Isa but
Mount Isa's way in the outback isn't it?

there's a signp there's a r u there's a signpost in Mount Isa it's eleven hundred and eight miles kilometres to Darwin eight eleven hundred and seven to Alice Springs and eleven hundred and five to Brisbane
yeah so I was out in Isa for
quite a time but the thought of working on top of a lead blast furnace in the middle of Australian desert
oh yeah not good not good
when I could've been retired in Stinchcombe
what did you do in Australia ?
I taught I taught at er which is just south of Brisbane just above the Gold Coast
where which is the the s it's called surfer's paradise
it isn't actually I don't think I think there are better places to surf in Australia but went erm my my ex erm exchangee partner he works in an outback school you go to Townsville
and then you just drive inland for about four hours and you get there
oh well Townsville's where our copper refinery was
and it iis the end of the railway line from Mount Isa of course
yeah yeah yeah so you just ca you could carry on and you would've got to Mount Isa
if you'd've wanted to go Mount Isa
if you wanted to go to Mount Isa yeah
yeah does it ring a bell? that's the town that he was at
school and it actually specialised in education it had about six boarding schools in the town and that's where most of the people were
was that you or your son?

he's he he went there and he just was a v like a teacher's assistant because I we we got in touch with who s and said he wants to you know do something in Australia and and I and I actually said to him while we were there visiting in nineteen in two thousand and three I said you know you'd do a lot wor you you could do a lot worse than come back here and i and honestly he had the time of his life
you know he went on all the trips that were being run and

it was just fantastic and and the outback kids I mean they i they were islander kids from the Torres strait but the outback kids were and it was like we had a meal with them all and you know in erm Harry Potter when everybody's sitting in that big dining room with all
it was like that they had a hall
and it was the dining room and all the teachers sitting on the top table

where we sat with and and then er the followi a a year or two after that was actually there as a member of staff and he he had a accommodation that he was he was sharing with a German and a Canadian girl I think he was the youngest there and and then all the kids it was a residential school so it was
and he he tells the story of used to go on all these trips with them and u u you know you know you know people get eaten by crocodiles occasionally in Australia
but they're never Australians they're usually German

and and he tells this story of they were staying on this on this sort of sandbank and erm ththere was there was water I think it was in the middle of a lake or something I don't know how they got there or i or they were just on the edge of a lake and it said no it must've been an island it was an island definitely and it said do not camp within fifteen metres of the shore but the island itself was only about twenty metres across

and it and then these got footage of him u they got th I don't know what it was it was some kind of tyre thing and and then he and and he set off u somebody driving a speed boat and with this thing chained to the back the and he and he takes off from the shore and and there's a sign behind him beware of crocodiles
and that's because they know it and they know so well
and then sleeping in a swag a swa have you ever seen a swag?
well the swag imagine erm an old fashioned shaped sleeping bag
but then you've got a hard almost waxy cover over it and you can pull it over your head and they're really heavy and that's what they sleep in
that's a swag and he slept out under the southern stars in swags with with with with the trip that they'd been on he went on every trip
every single weekend he was off doing something
and he had the time of his life
I always say to er I mean I well I've been fifteen times ain't I to Oz? but I've never seen anything at it's if there ain't a lead zinc silver mine or smelter I haven't been
which is like Scunthorpe or Rotherham on a wet
and Piri Port Piri oh g oh dear
so that's all I've ever seen of Oz I remember

the thing I like the best thing about Oz there are two things one is the light you can stand on top of the dividing range and you know you can see you feel as though you can see for a thousand mile you can probably see
you've got eagle eyes you can see for so far
and the second thing is the people no class system

well anyway we used to go to this pub on the corner in Brisbane on a Friday night and they used to there used to be businessmen and they wear shorts in they used to wear shorts in Brisbane I don't know if they still I think they've fallen out of fashion a bit
and a and a and a shirt with short sleeves no tie
but but but a sh a short sleeved proper stiff collar shirt and erm there there'd be all these businessmen with briefcases in and also people who look like tramps

and then a bloke would come round looking like a tramp just handing out free you know potatoes boiled in the jackets with butter on? loved them and i and and and i and i the everybody was equal and we remember

walking down the street and this tramp drop oh he was a paper seller wanted to drop he was he was selling newspapers and he was carrying his newspa and suddenly whoosh everything went everywhere and this really smart bloke in his suit just scooping it all up you know because no class system at all
yeah I spent a lot of time quite a lot of time in Brisbane but on street yeah
mm so were you teaching at the same school as wwas?
no no no erm the the
what what did you teach there?
was it very different from here?

they were d it was before we had a National Curriculum so everything was prescribed and I'd never come across a National Curriculum before I just thought you know like we used to make it up as we went along and just did topic work you know and if it was if it was snowing outside you just run outside

look at ice crystals or if the leaves suddenly st I remember being at here and it was the day when the oak tr no the horse chestnut s outside decided to lose its leaves and it did it every year and if you s if it was a really crisp frost day you could hear if you stood next to the tree you could hear the snap

so I'm standing there with the kids listening to all this snapping and it were just watching these leaves and they're huge things horse chestnut leaves and they were all spiralling down and that's what you used to do
when you were a primary school teacher and you were you were able to be creative and act spontaneously and have a lot of fun
it's just all prescribed and horrible
so in Australia what did you have to do?
well I I didn't because the files were this thick and and I taught with a woman who shared the classroom and I kind of tuned into what she was doing and kind of
I couldn't read these files I can't do it even if I'd sat there all night and read them it would've gone in o in one

side of me brain and out the other so I kind of looked at and just kind of made it up as I went along which seemed to be alright cos the parents came in and and thanked me and said they really enjoyed your class
probably cos I did a lot of art no it's
it that was a I couldn't believe it Queensland has a National Curriculum and erm I think
so what year what year are you talking about when you?
no but when were you there what what?
nineteen eighty-three I think yes nineteen eighty-three yeah cos the term first
eighty-th yeah that's the first year I went I was in Oz eighty-three
so were you married then to ? no?

no I met him in Queensland House on the Strand before we went and then he was going to Brisbane as well you see and he was getting so c see I h I I swapped house and car with this family and he thought he'd swapped a house with this chap but what he didn't realise was he was he e he always intended to buy his own car so we got out there and he bought his own car but what he didn't realise was he th he f he thought he had a house for himself then the wife came back
so and they didn't get on so he just moved into the house I'd got and that was it really
but imagine you know I would've been really dischuffed if I'd got to the you know I'd left him my house
and he'd left he'd left s there b him and his wife a beautiful house in cos he'd just done it fabulous place
so how old were you then? ?
I was thirty the year I was there I was thirty I turned thirty
and and was teaching as well
yeah he was teaching in a m in a yeah he was teaching what did they call it? they had a just it was like woodwork and CDT they call it here but he was

they called it something different there and it was really kind of old fashioned I think what he found cos Queensland joh Bjelke-Petersen was the Premier of Queensland when I was there and there was he it was hugely corrupt queensland

and there used to be a comedian who impersonated Joh Bjelke-Petersen on the telly who was absolutely brilliant and erm one of the scandals was that his son lived not quite in the outback but in a bit of a faraway place and and the Queensland government paved the road up to his house it was about sixty miles long
you know stupid things like that
and then his wife was called Flo and she made pumpkin tart and it was the Flo and Joh show

and everybody and and the rest of Australia I was flying into Que to er Brisbane and the chap next to me this is the first time I was going and the chap next to me erm he was an Aussie and he sai and the pilot came on and c tells us what temperature was and what time it was in Queensland and he said and and the time is cos you go over time zones cos I'd I'd f

gone to Perth first and then I was flying over to Queensland and to Brisbane and when he finished telling us what time to set our watches to and look that's the time he said and then put it back thirty years
and honestly when I got there I needed
I needed a loan right and so I did what I normally do cos I had my own house here and I used to bank in just north of Doncaster
and 's a pretty poor area and there was this one middle aged cashier and every time I walked in the bank cos everybody was poor then I mea it really a quite a deprived area
he used to race up to the thing cos he knew I had
you know I was having a salary paid in I was teaching
at the time and that I was
they used to rush to the front and so I was treated
like royalty when I walked in the bank
yes sir no sir anything you want

and erm I walked into this bank in shopping centre in Brisbane and it wasn't like a bank it was like it was just a counter there was no there was no security there was no glass there was nothing there was no barrier it was just a counter and then the tellers were behind it and it not only that you could walk from the outside car park through the bank like you can here sometimes you can walk through shops into the main mall into the middle bit where
you've got all the cafés and things so it was just a robbery waiting to happen I couldn't

believe it you know but it was so but anyway I wanted a loan and I had to go and see the bank manager so I went in and he talked to me like I was a little girl and and he a he refused me my loan and so my teaching partner said well go again and take a bloke with you said don't matter who you take just take anybody just drag him in off the street
so I took with me and w had daps on jeans er and like a bomber jacket thing and he sat there next to me and he looked like a freak you know like people used to look looking back he looked like
I watched Freddie Mercury he was that kind of style
and er and I got me loan
and he but he was guarantor
and I just felt like a child
that's typical that's typical of Queensland that is my god it's poor
that's how I was being treated queensland honestly unbelievable
it's not like that now though I don't think it's covered in mosques for a start masses of mosques
is it? I haven't been there
masses loads of Saudis on holiday buying c they've got a thing about candles all buying candles
oh oh right oh cos I ret I've been retired from eighteen years now I retired fifty-five and went and did a part time job
so when were you last in Australia?
well it has ch it has changed a lot

Austr er Australia and said never never again erm but u when I moved down to in ninety-one I didn't wanna come come down a r a cos it's cos we had a crematorium running that and I said I'll do it for five years and I'll get out u and I did five years to the day
packed it up and went and worked for a haulage company
but er anyway I'm gonna have to think about going now cos I wanna ring my sister's carer and er see if I can get her sorted
well if you if you want any more chat we'll do we'll do it ano again in a few if you're going there
what we need to be able to do it again over a bottle of wine and 'll have to drive
but I thought that you two would revert to some really strange dialect or language coming from Sheffield but you sound
but you sound to me completely usual
what you've got to do well I you should've recorded me on Saturday nights sitting with my mum's family
a th using the dialect and missing the thes out
and they were I said after a while I said you know it's great sitting here with people
because people don't say in'tit where I come from
where I where I live now and erm
and they they i w was talking about erm on the telly when they try to do a Yorkshire accent and they they do if you if you
something like I'm just going tut shops
and I'm I'm just going down t' park
you miss the the out completely
and yet they try to put a little tuh in it and it sounds so false
if a a a York it it grates doesn't it when they
try to do the Yorkshire accent?
no and I talk quite differently when my sister was in Sheffield cos I haven't been to Sheffield now for quite a few years
but I talk quite differently when I
yeah yeah well I only have to go into Sh into Hillsborough cos uu we shop at Hillsborough sometimes me and me mum cos there's loads of
cheap shops and when I'm speaking to the greengrocer and the
people behind the till I d I I mimic them
mm I notice I I've noticed now that I'm not talking any differently now to what I've been talking for ten fifteen years but if if I go
now one of us'd have to start doing it and then the other would start as well
you better bring your parents down
but they don't actually use that now because
they they lost it at grammar school you see
but I but you'd have to bring my mum's family home who who stayed in the East of Sheffield
say the other night he said something like ey up how's tha?
ey up how's that? actually ey up is a Doncaster expression but how's tha? is how are you?
rea it it he said I can't bring it to mind but I understood it straight away and I can do it back
yeah but think of the problem I had when I had when I went and worked up in Glas
yeah well this is it it's
I went to work in Glasgow I couldn't understand what they were talking about
and they couldn't understand what I was talking about
and then I came down here I couldn't get on with you lot eh I in fact I was down in Bristol three weeks I asked if I could go back
what cos you? cos of the language?
well you could be dead for three weeks down Bristol and nobody'd know
I tell you what that I have a great deal of trouble cos I at the l my last school before I came down here was the was in the Socialist Republic of South Yorkshire

and I came to I was working at and they were talking about coming in and painting the classrooms at the holidays so I've started to laugh I thought they were joking I mean to suggest to a bunch of teachers in South Yorkshire that they come in in their
and they paint their own flipping classrooms
but I I noticed and I realised that they weren't joking and I thought you know I'm living in a parallel uni
they just didn't get and also some of the stuff that I said I've stopped
do I had to stop but I would say things to people and they would take offence
I can't remember now because I stopped doing it but
but quite erm you know you'd say things to people up north and they'd just laugh
say things to people down here and they just gape at you
oh it was well knknknown a Socialist Republic weren't it South Yorkshire?
well imagine that staffroom it was a middle school it had as many men in it
and we were really really union orientated
and very very huge huge socialist I remember somebody saying what what's the what's the erm? what's the? you know like a gaggle of geese and pride of lions what is it?
what's the collective noun for a group of teachers and some dry wit said it's the Labour Party
yeah no that's about right innit?
we'll do it again we'll we'll put an invoice in next time
thanks for the tea well we'll do it again as soon as we can
thank you very much for coming
well I must go and er
